posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
After this season, my team and I were 100% not pleased with our wiring and wanted to improve it for future seasons. However, we wanted to know how others handled wire management while also making their wiring look neat and easily accessible.

A quick rundown of our wiring included using heat shrink to connect wires and prevent tangling. But whenever we faced a CAN issue, we had to cut the wire open to access it, which took too long. Other wires on our robot often became tangled, and we frequently used WAGO connectors or similar pieces because we needed to splice multiple wire segments. We planned to get longer rolls of wire in the future.

Additionally, I explored nylon wraps and different wire types after a competition inspector mentioned we were still using outdated wire that was hard to manage. Many other teams used newer wire, but I wasn't sure and still don't know exactly what type he was referring to.

If anyone has suggestions or knows about the type of wire the inspector mentioned, I would be very grateful.

link_counts.title: Under‑performing our capabilities, Looking for Advice

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: We used heat shrink to keep moving wires hooked together to prevent wire entanglement in our chains, however, whenever we encountered a CAN issue, we'd have to cut into it to access it, and it took way too long. Split loom slewing is great for this. It was an absolute game-changer for our team this season.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: Something like this? Amazon.com: Braided Split Wire Loom Wrap Cable Sleeve Tube Harness Lot Sheathing Management Organize (3/8'-15ft): Electronics. Priced at $18.99.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked: We use the split wire looms and zip ties.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Looks like it'll work great to me. These are what we use and they're a bit cheaper if you want to save on costs but both would work fantastically.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: Awesome, thank you!

We used +1 on the sleeves heavily on our robot for the baseplate this year. We like to use cable sleeving for some of our smaller wires, such as CAN, 18AWG power to CANcoders, Pigeons, and others, to help keep them together. If you're looking for suggestions, this particular cable sleeving (not this specific brand) has worked well for us in the past. Without knowing the exact wording, it could just be that your wire is old and crusty and is hard to bend. We actually got new wire this year from PowerWerx, and we have been very happy with both the quality and the flexibility. 

We also found that using WAGO’s or other connector pieces helped with a lot of connections. I highly recommend learning to solder for CAN and 18AWG cables (please don't solder 12AWG). We switched to soldering everything this year, and we never had an electrical problem at all during any of our competitions. It also makes CAN runs easier since you don’t have a massive connector in the way. Anderson Powerpoles are another favorite of mine, especially when you put a ziptie through the holes in the connector to zip-tie them together—it makes the whole thing bulletproof. 

My personal tip for cable management is to keep bundles together with zipties. Proper strain relief is also crucial to prevent wires from becoming unplugged. For example, we had our cable runs all zip tied together to support each other and keep them in one spot, making the entire bundle easier to route.

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: We switched to soldering our CANs together because we had issues with wagons during Belton, so for our San Antonio and State event, we had them soldered. But why not solder 12 awg?

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
We had to continuously use multiple sections of wire because we didn’t have long rolls. Everyone is focused on the split loom nylon protectors, which is exactly what you should do, but this issue here is even bigger, and I’m glad you recognize you need to fix it. You took a wire that should only have two points of failure—at either end—and added several more along the way. That’s why you kept having to cut apart your heat shrink to access each section.  

In 2023, we dealt with this same problem when our wiring wasn’t set up properly, and it cost us multiple matches. Considering how expensive regionals, travel, and the robot are, every lost match felt like wasted money. Instead of struggling with shortened wires and frequent repairs, we completely revamped our wiring system. If you’re curious, here’s a writeup about how we switched to using rally sport wires and connectors. In the two years since, we haven’t encountered a single wiring issue during a competition.  

Personally, I’m not a big fan of soldering—it works well, but if you’re not careful, especially if you’re a student new to soldering, a poor job could lead to issues down the line. However, diagnosing a bad solder connection is tricky, so problems often show up only when it’s too late.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked:
We faced significant issues with soldering, and due to time constraints, we reverted to using ferrel connectors and wagos. However, the root cause of our wire shortages stemmed from issues with our prior year's team members and district limitations. Last season, our members lacked initiative and failed to innovate, leading our programming lead to rely heavily on external code. Our build team consistently used incorrect templates, resulting in flawed designs, while our wiring suffered from insufficient funding and neglect.  

This year, as programming lead, I took the initiative to learn extensively and train the team, yet our progress remained hindered by the previous members' lack of organization and their tendency to break equipment. This led to wiring shortages and delays in ordering supplies due to the district's lengthy approval process, which often took two weeks. By the time materials arrived, many of our rio modules were fried, forcing us to scramble during competition. Additionally, securing a new computer proved challenging, as the district required administrative controls that limited our access.  

Despite these obstacles, I am committed to turning things around. I plan to thoroughly assess and organize our electrical components, identify redundancies, and rewiring the robots to function efficiently. While my earlier remarks may have sounded harsh, they were not intended to be disrespectful. I aim to implement better practices, such as using single-strand wires and nylon wraps, to ensure future success. Thank you for your understanding and support.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
I’m sorry to hear you’ve been going through so much trouble. Purchasing is definitely one of the most inconvenient processes any team (or anyone at a company) goes through. For many years, I’ve just been buying things for the team without getting reimbursed because it seemed less of a hassle to just cover the cost myself. However, this year, I purchased some items for the team that were expensive enough to justify reimbursement, though it was still a challenge involving a school foundation and ASB.

While for your team, it makes sense to invest in a spool of high-quality wire costing between $50 and $100, given that a single match can cost over $400 to enter, it’s frustrating to explain this logic to a school finance administrator. To avoid delays, it’s best to stock up as much as possible during the fall season. Regardless of the competition, you’ll inevitably need CAN wire.

I wish you luck in acquiring new wires and electronics.

A helpful tip regarding the driver station: consider asking a sponsor if they have leftover laptops (often schools are discarding perfectly good machines due to Windows 11 compatibility issues). Keep the donation quiet to prevent the school from becoming aware and potentially restricting access.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.name: Kade Dressing
posts.cooked: We are receiving new CAN wire (25’) and may receive additional supplies. For the computer, we were already planning an upgrade. A sponsor, my father’s friend, offered to purchase a new one, but due to funding issues, this didn’t materialize. We will explore alternative sponsorship options. I agree with you about challenging school rules that seem unreasonable.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: What problems did you have with your CAN+wago? We did that last year and had no failures. Additionally, we used appropriate gauge ferrules, which is essential due to the small wire (22ga). The wire needs to be strain relieved. However, it must be done correctly—a common initial error was not having the wire all the way to the end of the ferrule. This year, we switched to Molex-SL connectors, which require slightly more work and skill initially but are smaller (and much faster and easier to connect).

posts.name: Olivia
posts.cooked: What kind of zip ties do you use to zip tie your powerpole connectors together? This sounds better than the clips but we don’t have zipties small enough to fit through the connector holes.

posts.name: bgg
posts.cooked: We used solder seal wire connectors for the first time this year and will continue using them on our robots in the future. These connectors were primarily employed to create short Controller Area Network (CAN) branches for each motor controller. This added an extra layer of safety, ensuring the entire system would remain operational even if a single branch encountered issues. Notably, we experienced zero CAN-related problems across three separate events. Additionally, I recommend upgrading to Thrifty Nova CAN cables as a suitable replacement for SPARK MAX users. The robot also had hot glue applied to every connector that required wiring, though this can be easily removed with alcohol if needed.

posts.name: Jai Gupta
posts.cooked: We love using adhesive cable tie mounts, McMaster slit corrugated tubing, and braided sleeving. We also plan wire routing during the design process to ensure our designs are electrically friendly and incorporate cable tie mounts in 3D-printed parts. This allows us to be highly efficient when wiring and have a step-by-step plan with prepped (one end crimped, one end uncrimped with slack) wires.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
I also am a big fan of Anderson Powerpoles, especially when you put a ziptie through the holes in the connector to zip-tie them together, makes it bulletproof.

The Powerpole Pins make this even better, I love powerpoles so much for this application and the pins make them faster to swap while still being stronger than a tiny ziptie.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Powerwerx PCLIP Retention Clips for PP15/30/45 Anderson Power Powerpole Connectors (25 pieces) : Electronics

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked: You don’t need to go through the tiny holes; instead, just go around the whole dang thing (and between the wires), and then you can use reasonably sized zip ties.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Nick Foote - 2102 Team Paradox - Engineering Mentor and Founding Student

posts.cooked:
To address the challenge of obtaining a suitable computer for work while adhering to the district's security measures, here's a structured plan:

1. **Use Personal Computer Securely**: Utilize my personal computer at home, ensuring it is equipped with robust security measures such as antivirus software and strong passwords. This allows me to access necessary tools without exposing my device to potential risks.

2. **Explore Remote Access Solutions**: Implement secure methods like VPNs or encrypted connections to remotely access district systems. This approach keeps my personal devices protected while maintaining connectivity to essential tools and resources.

3. **Request Limited Admin Access**: Engage with the tech department to seek limited admin privileges during remote sessions. This controlled access can support running required programs without compromising overall system security.

4. **Consult District Policies**: Review and understand the district's IT policies to ensure compliance. This knowledge will guide interactions with the tech department and inform decision-making processes.

By integrating these strategies, I aim to find a balance between security requirements and functional capabilities, ensuring efficient job performance while respecting the district's policies.
We just use small zip ties that fit in the hole or wrap around the powerpole connectors. They will work well as long as you have the right size.
